Title: Sensory and premotor connections of the orbital and medial prefrontal cortex

@BrainMaps.Comments: This is the companion article of CP95a. Both articles use the map of CP94 for prefrontal and premotor areas.

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Comments: For some areas, this article refers to several other parcellation schemes, for other areas there is no reference at all. These ambiguities are especially obvious for (para-)insular, sensory, and temporal areas.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "...the connections and physiological responses of areas SII and 7b have been described (Robinson and Burton, 1980b; Friedman and Murray, 1986; Neal et al., 1987; Cavada and Goldman-Rakic, 1989a; Andersen et al., 1990; Burton and Fabri, 1994)..." (p.656)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The reference to Burton and Fabri wrongly states that the paper was published  in 1994; the actual year of publication was 1995.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "...the connections and physiological responses of areas SII and 7b have been described (Robinson and Burton, 1980b; Friedman and Murray, 1986; Neal et al., 1987; Cavada and Goldman-Rakic, 1989a; Andersen et al., 1990; Burton and Fabri, 1994)..." (p.656)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The reference to Burton and Fabri wrongly states that the paper was published  in 1994; the actual year of publication was 1995.

Area 35 is not mentioned by the text, but appears as a delineated area in Fig. 7. CP95a and CP95b are "companion papers", thus it seems reasonable to assume that area CP95b-35 is identically defined as CP95a-36.

Area 36 is not mentioned by the text, but appears as a delineated area in Fig. 7. CP95a and CP95b are "companion papers", thus it seems reasonable to assume that area CP95b-36 is identically defined as CP95a-36.

It is not explicitly stated according to what map the dysgranular insular area Id was defined in this article. We therefore refer to a standard article for the definition of the dysgranular insular area (Mesulam and Mufson, 1982a) and assume that CP95b-Id is identical to MM82a-Idg.

It is not explicitly stated according to what map area Ig was defined in this article. We therefore refer to a standard article for the definition of Ig (Mesulam and Mufson, 1982a) and assume that CP95b-Ig is identical to MM82a-Ig.

Area LA (designated "lateral auditory area" by CP95b) is not described in the text, but is shown in Figs. 3+4. From its location and name, one can assume that it is identical to the "lateral auditory field" L of MB73.
Although no direct reference is given in the text, a comparison of nomenclature and location let it seem plausible to assume that area PI of CP95b is identical to area PI of MMM87.

Area RA (designated "rostral auditory area" by CP95b) is not described in the text, but is shown in Figs. 3+4. From its location and name, one can assume that it is identical to the "rostrolateral auditory field" RL of MB73.
No relation is explicitly stated for area TF. We thus assume that it is defined according to the standard map for TF, i.e. BB47.

Area TPag is not mentioned by the text, but appears as a delineated area in Figs. 3, 4, 7. CP95a and CP95b are "companion papers", thus it seems reasonable to assume that area CP95b-TPag is identically defined as CP95a-TPag.

Area TPdgd is not mentioned by the text, but appears as a delineated area in Figs. 3, 4. CP95a and CP95b are "companion papers", thus it seems reasonable to assume that area CP95b-TPdgd is identically defined as CP95a-TPdgd.

Area TPdgv is not mentioned by the text, but appears as a delineated area in Figs. 3, 4, 7. CP95a and CP95b are "companion papers", thus it seems reasonable to assume that area CP95b-TPdgv is identically defined as CP95a-TPdgv.
There is no statement according to what parcellation scheme area 3a is be defined. We thus refer to a standard map for area 3a (Jones & Burton 1976) and assume that CP95b-3a is identical to JB76-3a.
There is no statement according to what parcellation scheme area 3b is be defined. We thus refer to a standard map for area 3b (Jones & Burton 1976) and assume that CP95b-3b is identical to JB76-3b.

It is not explicitly stated according to what map area 7a was defined in this article. We therefore refer to a standard article for the definition of 7a (Andersen et al., 1985) and assume that CP95b-7a is identical to AAC85-7a.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "...the parainsular cortex (PI) in the inferior limiting sulcus...The labeled neurons were located in a large region of PI that stretches from a level near the middle portion of the amygdala to a point near the caudal end of the uncus of the hippocampus. This stretch of PI appears to include areas paraI and proA of Galaburda and Pandya (1983)." (p. 651)

"...the parainsular cortex (PI) in the inferior limiting sulcus...The labeled neurons were located in a large region of PI that stretches from a level near the middle portion of the amygdala to a point near the caudal end of the uncus of the hippocampus. This stretch of PI appears to include areas paraI and proA of Galaburda and Pandya (1983)." (p. 651)

"...cells were labeled throughout the rostrocaudal extent of Bonin and Bailey's field TE (Bonin and Bailey, 1947), which, as used here, extends along the inferior temporal gyrus from the granular temporal polar area (TPg; Carmichael and Price, 1995) rostrally to the boundary with architectonic area TEO near the anterior tip of the posterior medial temporal sulcus caudally (Boussaoud et al., 1991). This definition includes the anterior and central inferior temporal fields of Van Essen et al. (1990)." (p. 644)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Anterior and central inferior temporal fields of Van Essen et al. (1990: AITd, AITv, CITd, CITv

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "...cells were labeled throughout the rostrocaudal extent of Bonin and Bailey's field TE (Bonin and Bailey, 1947), which, as used here, extends along the inferior temporal gyrus from the granular temporal polar area (TPg; Carmichael and Price, 1995) rostrally to the boundary with architectonic area TEO near the anterior tip of the posterior medial temporal sulcus caudally (Boussaoud et al., 1991). This definition includes the anterior and central inferior temporal fields of Van Essen et al. (1990)." (p. 644)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Anterior and central inferior temporal fields of Van Essen et al. (1990: AITd, AITv, CITd, CITv

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "...cells were labeled throughout the rostrocaudal extent of Bonin and Bailey's field TE (Bonin and Bailey, 1947), which, as used here, extends along the inferior temporal gyrus from the granular temporal polar area (TPg; Carmichael and Price, 1995) rostrally to the boundary with architectonic area TEO near the anterior tip of the posterior medial temporal sulcus caudally (Boussaoud et al., 1991). This definition includes the anterior and central inferior temporal fields of Van Essen et al. (1990)." (p. 644)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Anterior and central inferior temporal fields of Van Essen et al. (1990: AITd, AITv, CITd, CITv

@InterMapRelations.Citation: p. 650: " [The superior temporal cortex] Rostral to the level of the anterior tip of the central sulcus...The superior temporal cortex posterior to this level (extending to the caudal edge of the insula...These two regions will be referred to as anterior and posterior parts of the superior temporal gyral cortex (STGa and STGp, respectively)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Compare location of Area TA of BB47 (BB47, Figs. 14-24) to that of STGa / STGp (CP95b, Figs. 1-4, 6-7).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: p. 650: " [The superior temporal cortex] Rostral to the level of the anterior tip of the central sulcus...The superior temporal cortex posterior to this level (extending to the caudal edge of the insula...These two regions will be referred to as anterior and posterior parts of the superior temporal gyral cortex (STGa and STGp, respectively)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Compare location of Area TA of BB47 (BB47, Figs. 14-24) to that of STGa / STGp (CP95b, Figs. 1-4, 6-7).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "At least three subdivisions can be recognized within the superior temporal cortex...In keeping with previous classifications (Moran et al., 1987; Carmichael and Price, 1995) the anterior region is termed the TPg." (pp. 649-650)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: CP95a and CP95b are "companion papers", thus it seems reasonable to assume that area CP95b-TPg is identically defined as CP95a-TPg.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "At least three subdivisions can be recognized within the superior temporal cortex...In keeping with previous classifications (Moran et al., 1987; Carmichael and Price, 1995) the anterior region is termed the TPg." (pp. 649-650)

"In the opercular part of area 1-2, the cells labeled from area 12m were located near the border with the gustatory cortex...Although some authors have distinguished areas 1 and 2 in this region (Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1989), it appears sufficiently uniform in myelin and Nissl stains that we have retained the terminology of Roberts and Akert (1963), in which the two fields were not separated." (p. 647)

"...the connections and physiological responses of areas SII and 7b have been described (Robinson and Burton, 1980b; Friedman and Murray, 1986; Neal et al., 1987; Cavada and Goldman-Rakic, 1989a; Andersen et al., 1990; Burton and Fabri, 1994)..." (p. 656)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The reference to Burton and Fabri wrongly states that the paper was published in 1994; the actual year of publication was 1995.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "...the rostral part of the ventral bank of the intraparietal sulcus, dorsally adjacent to area 7b (Fig. 2D). This region appears to correspond to AIP (Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1991)..." (p. 648)
"...the region of dorsal area 6 that has been identified as the SEF (Schlag and Schlag-Rey, 1987; Huerta and Kaas, 1990)..." (p. 654)
"...the region of dorsal area 6 that has been identified as the SEF (Schlag and Schlag-Rey, 1987; Huerta and Kaas, 1990)..." (p. 654)

publication.title: Sensory and premotor connections of the orbital and medial prefrontal cortex
